message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented by the patient suggest Meckel diverticulum, as it is common in children and presents with abdominal pain that starts around the umbilicus and radiates to the right lower quadrant, accompanied by vomiting. The concentric rings of bowel seen on ultrasound can also be a characteristic finding of Meckel diverticulum. Appendicitis usually presents with pain starting around the belly button and later moving to the right lower quadrant, and malrotation with volvulus presents with bilious vomiting and a distended abdomen, which are not seen in this patient. Intestinal adhesions may be a cause of recurrent abdominal pain, but they do not present with the specific symptoms seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the location and radiation of pain and vomiting, suggest Meckel diverticulum. The ultrasound finding of concentric rings of bowel also supports this diagnosis. Intestinal adhesions might cause abdominal pain and bowel obstruction, but they are less likely to cause location-specific pain and vomiting. Acute appendicitis typically causes right lower quadrant pain without radiation to the umbilical region. Malrotation with volvulus can cause vomiting and abdominal pain, but it usually presents earlier in life and with more severe symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with Meckel diverticulum, as it can cause abdominal pain, vomiting, and tenderness in the lower right abdomen. The ultrasound also shows concentric rings of bowel, which is a characteristic finding in Meckel diverticulum. Intestinal adhesions may cause similar symptoms, but the ultrasound findings would be different. Acute appendicitis may also cause lower right abdominal pain, but the drawn-up knees and concentric rings on ultrasound are not typical. Malrotation with volvulus may cause abdominal pain and vomiting, but it would also lead to significant changes in laboratory values, which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of acute intermittent umbilical abdominal pain that radiates to the right lower abdomen and periumbilical tenderness suggest a possible diagnosis of Meckel diverticulum. The presence of concentric rings of bowel in transverse section seen on abdominal ultrasound is also consistent with Meckel diverticulum. Intestinal adhesions typically present with chronic abdominal pain and distension, while acute appendicitis presents with pain that initially starts in the periumbilical region before migrating to the right lower quadrant. Malrotation with volvulus can present with similar symptoms but typically presents earlier in infancy with bilious vomiting and a distended abdomen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of acute intermittent abdominal pain that radiates to the right lower abdomen, nonbilious vomiting, and drawing of knees to the chest suggest Meckel diverticulum, which is a common cause of lower abdominal pain in young children. The ultrasound confirms the presence of concentric rings of bowel in transverse section, which is typical of Meckel diverticulum. Other options, such as intestinal adhesions, acute appendicitis, and malrotation with volvulus, may also present with abdominal pain but have different characteristics and presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including intermittent umbilical abdominal pain that radiates to the right lower abdomen, nonbilious vomiting, drawing up knees to the chest and the ultrasound showing concentric rings of bowel suggest Meckel diverticulum as the most likely underlying cause. Intestinal adhesions may cause bowel obstruction but not intermittent abdominal pain. Acute appendicitis may cause lower right quadrant pain, however, the periumbilical tenderness suggests otherwise. Malrotation with volvulus may cause vomiting and abdominal distension, but not the specific pattern of pain described in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms point towards Meckel diverticulum, which can result in acute abdominal pain, vomiting, and tenderness. The ultrasound showing concentric rings of bowel in transverse section is also suggestive of Meckel diverticulum. Intestinal adhesions, acute appendicitis, and malrotation with volvulus can also cause similar symptoms, but the imaging findings and patient history are more consistent with Meckel diverticulum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest acute appendicitis, but the ultrasound shows concentric rings of bowel in transverse section, which is highly suggestive of a Meckel diverticulum. This condition occurs in 2% of the population and can cause symptoms that mimic acute appendicitis. The leukocyte count and abdominal tenderness suggest an inflammatory process, which can occur with either condition. Intestinal adhesions are usually caused by prior surgery or infection, and malrotation with volvulus typically presents with bilious vomiting, which this patient does not have.

We refer to the Mayo Clinic article on Meckel's diverticulum for help. The patient's symptoms, including umbilical abdominal pain, radiating pain to the right lower abdomen, and drawing up knees to the chest, are consistent with Meckel's diverticulum. The presence of concentric rings of bowel on ultrasound also supports this diagnosis. The other options are less likely based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that the most likely underlying cause is Meckel diverticulum, which can present with intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and tenderness. The ultrasound findings of concentric rings of bowel in transverse section are consistent with bowel obstruction often seen with Meckel diverticulum. Intestinal adhesions may also cause bowel obstruction, but they usually present with a history of previous surgery. Acute appendicitis typically presents with pain that localizes to the right lower quadrant and may become constant once inflammation sets in. Malrotation with volvulus usually presents in young infants with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension.
